Stevens Point Mar 20 '96 Dear Mother. I write a few this morning to let you know how things are going - Dan goes right ahead on the house regardless of my wishes. He is going to cut the folding doors through from the old part to the new. I don't want it done as I didnt want it touched until it can be finished up entirely papered & everything and another thing he is going to finish it in pure? I wanted the dining room finished in hard wood to match the furnature. We have to have a bed in the room & it will just?

the casings all up. I want you to put a stop to his doing any more on the house with out he can do as I wish. I had rather go all my life without any more room then to be kicked & pounded and cursed at all the time. I had rather leave the house the way it is for years and finish only one room at a time then to be used as I am. I wont stand it and I want you to tell him he need not do any more on the house with out he complies with my wishes when& how it shall be done. He is just cutting the doors through to be mean to have his own way: as it will knock me out of what little room I have; as I shall have to put the sofa

up in the stove room. & will make it so much colder toward the doors. then it would be the solid wall. I wanted to wait until it got warmer & then move into the new part & have the floors laid in this part & all finished up, but no. he going to unclear up & make me all the work he can for nothing: & will have it all to do over again. I won't be tormented by him any longer about the house. If we cant hire the rest of it I done: it will never be finished: with out you are here to tell him what you want done & how. He says its none of my business: he will do as he has a mind to: that I havent any thing to say about it. I dont want him to

do any more on it. Alice is getting along very nicely with her whooping cough. - I have it. so you may know i feel real nice. I shall be thankful when it comes warm. if that time ever draws near. If it was a little warmer I would take Alice & drive down to Brandon. I had a letter from Uncle John. - they are well - I guess Grace & Haddie are doing first rate on the Hasen? place. They just sold their hogs & their share came to $175.00 partly good wasnt it. Good bye Ma. From your Mary - Love & a kiss.

Stevens Point Mar. 26 '96 Dear Mother. I have first got Alice to sleep so will sit down to write a few lines so I can mail it on the night train. I must tell you about my disappointment an happiness. Sunday was my Birthday and I looked for a letter from you Saturday night but it failed to come but Monday morning the Postman brought me one also a box. The letter contained a check for $5.00 and as for the box it was first full of everything nice & first what I needed. as for Alice she was delighted.

This is the way she expressed herself "I feel first like crying for all those sweet things." All that bothers me I never have anything to send to you. The comb & side combs were awful nice in fact all the things were. Those toilet pins are handsome never see any like them before. I must tell you what a magic my writing to you made on Dan he knew I wrote to you but didnt know just what but surmised the contents and ever since he has gone on and done as I wanted him to. Today your letter came for him and he was away so I took the handkerchief out but did not give the letter to him he never surmised but what the letter was for me didnt ask so didnt tell him. When he come

I handed him the handkerchief and told him you forgot to put it in the box. Wasnt that a good one. He is building the porch now when finished the outside will be all done but the steps & walks If I have it painted this Summer I shall have to have it painted right away: as it is liable to come a hard wind later one & fill it full of sand. - now it is not dry enough to blow. - when he gets the work done he primes? it right over so as to keep the wood. - but he couldnt do a nice job of painting in two or three colors. I hate to let it go until another Spring: for it adds so much to a place to be painted. One can't see what the work is until painted.

I can get trusted for the paint. the work will be about $20.00 What shall I do about it. Let me know by return mail. The side porch he is making now: is going to be so nice. it will be so pleasant to sit on afternoons. and for Alice to play on. It is off the dining room. Dan is getting a Michigan fever. - he thinks he would like to go thare and get a place so as to raise fruit. I wouldnt want to go. but he can go and see how he likes it if he wants. If he should go this Summer, he would have to sell one of the lots in Oshkosh. to go with. & that would have us one lot clear of debt. - he said if he went he

When did you see Uncle Emery & the girls last. Have you ever seen Ella Cole or she that used to be. would send us $10.00 a month. If he could get some property there so much the better for me. I am willing he should try it, if he wants to. Wouldn't you be. Be sure & tell me when you write, first what you think about it dont forget The taxes are all paid & I have $41.00 on hand but if I get the house painted it will take $20.00 for the work & the rest I want to pay on the lumber. This has been a very pleasant day but cold raw winds. We have had a very mild Winter only about two weeks sleighing. It seems green enough to run wagons

the year round. I have 11 hens  - my rooster died the other day dont know what ailed him. I wish I could send away for a setting? of Houdan eggs They cost about $1.50 per setting. I have some houdans but none that are full bloods - Alice is getting along nicely with her whooping cough. I cough just the same as she does. but don't whoop. but vomit almost every time I cough. It will soon be warm now & I shall be so glad. Then we can both get out. Do you ever see any tramps there. The commence to get quite numerous around here. I must close - Good bye - From your Mary Love & a kiss. Write Soon

Stevens Point May 29 "96 Dear Mother. The boxes have just arrived so will sit right down to let you know about them. I went to the freight depot six different times: while at last they came. I don't know how to thank you for all the things. I'm afraid you robbed yourself. I bet you didnt have one bit of maple sugar. It is splendid the first I have tasted of this year. We had some melted last night for supper. All I do is to feast. I went to the depot and got the things. but send me one in your next letter. Tomorrow is Decoration Day. I consider it the most glorious of all the days. If I only knew where Pa was sleeping: so I could wear a garland for him. Love & a  kiss. I will say good bye. Your Mary.

could not carry them into the house. I couldnt wait until Dan came at night so opened them right out doors. As it happened I got the box that had the groceries in first I was perfectlly bewildered. I never see any thing so well packed, there wasn't an inch of room to spare. I don't know what to tell of first. Well: I wish you could have seen Alice she was so pleased with all her things, especially the pocket book and didn't she open her eyes when she found the money in it. The dress fitted her exactly. the sleeves a little short, will sew some lace in them. I think it is awful pretty. Did you buy it all ready made. My shirt waist

belt & writing set are handsome. I cant wear the other waists they are too small for me. I was awful sorry Thanks for the aprons & towels just what I wanted. The cans came all right I opened the pint can of black raspberries they tasted like old times. Those sweet pickles are splendid. Did you put them up yourself. I have groceries to last a long time. I never had as many raisins at one time before. That is the nicest butter I have had this summer. It is so sweet & good. How much did you have to pay for it per pound. I have commenced to take that medicine. It will

do me good, as I feel better so soon. All I can do is to thank you for the things. The neighbors all envy me all those nice things. What terrible storms they are having all around us- Wednesday St Louis was swept by a Tornado and full 1000 lives lost - if not more. Lots of smaller towns in Mo. Iowa & Ill. were swept from the earth. At Drake a school house was blown down and 80 children killed. A cyclone raged in Michigan the day before & at one place 42 were killed. We have escaped so far. I was always afraid in a thunderstorm any way. Wasnt you? The $1.00 you sent in the letter I got me a new dress with. I think it is awful pretty. As soon as I can am going to have some pictures taken. get yours taken &

Stevens Point July 13. Dear mother. I must write to you while I am getting supper. I should have written before but have been very busy. That medicine you sent has done me lots of good. I am very choice of it. I look it and by the time the Advents had their Camp Meeting across from us I felt well enough to run a stand. I cleared ten dollars $10.00 in all and am saving it until you come before I buy any thing with it and since the I have been after blueberries I have ten My skirt measurement is 42 inches in length & belt 30 inches. I guess I will weight 200 if I keep on. I don't believe you would know me I am so much larger then I was when you saw me last. Are you

cans in all & two of gooseberries I feel better when I am out doors. so I am going to stay out all I can for it will soon be cold weather. I hope this will find you well. I had a letter from down home and what do you think for news. Uncle John's Wife is going to have a baby. I'm afraid his clothes wont hold him. Uncle Johns Brother - Charley is living with them, is going to play as long as he lives. I'm going to drive down thare as soon as the Crusader's have their Camp meeting. They have it the 1st of August across from us. I'm going to keep a stand . I hope I can make $10.00. I will try. I got a letter from you while I just as thin as you used to be. I must close & get supper. Good bye Your Mary. Love & a kiss.

had the stand & it contained $1.00 bill gloves & stamps. The other day I got a package. in it was a dress for Alice, apron for me & outing set. The things are very nice. That little dress was awful pretty. How much did you pay for it.  She wore the first one you sent her this Fourth. we went out to Stockton visiting. Had a nice time. I had to put my letter to one side as I had callers come in. Will try and finish it now. This has been a terrible hot day. I hope we won't get a bad storm. When are you going to start for home. Don't come across the Lake, what if it

does cost a little more the other way. I have a nice garden. Have had string beans & cucumbers out of it and am ready now to put down cucumbers for Winter. How did you fix those sweet cucumbers you sent. They were the nicest I ever tasted of. I don't eat a sour pickle of any kind. I have just had a treat. Cracked some hickory nuts for Alice and I. She is asleep. how pleased she will be when she wakes up and finds them and when I get done writing will have a taste of maple sugar. I have a taste almost every day. I melted some once

Mr Acker & Sarah are miserable I don't think they will last much longer. They live in Brandon. Ruby teaches school in Brandon. They like her very much. Charley Acker is married and lives in Oragon. Rosa lives in Oshkosh. She has three children. Her baby is about a year old. Mr. & Mrs. Horton are both glad. The farm is sold & Isadore lives in Brandon. Thare is a big change in that neighbor hood. I want to drive down, but dont want to break into my $10.00 It doesnt cost much to go overland only for hay and bed. Why wont you get your

picture taken and send me one. NOw do and send when you write again, I wished you had been here the Fourth, I think of you every day and wish so much to see you. By good rights I ought to go out to Minn. The man that is on the place now, wants it another year. & yesterday I got a letter from another party & they want it. I think by going I might rent it to better atvantage & see what shape the land is in. I wont give either party an answer until I hear from you. I guess you will think you have a newspaper, when you get this A thousand thanks for the things you sent. Every one envies me of all my nice things.

Stevens Point. July 23. 96. Dear Mother. I rec'd your letter yesterday containing Pension Draft and Money Order for $5.00 also a Two Dollar bill. I'm much obliged for the Two Dollars: & will keep it until you come. I have $12.00 now. I hope this will find you well. I am feeling real well for me and want to keep so. I wish I could clear $10.00 with the stand. Perhaps I can. It is very hard work but I don't mind that if I am only well. Dan had a little siding to put on one of Now write as soon as you get this. Love & a kiss

the porches and then the outside of the house is all done. The partitions are all set and some of the lathing done. Wall plaster as soon after the crusaiders? go as possible. Wall plaster up stairs & down but it we cant finish the upstairs right away it doesnt matter; as we can use the front room for a bedroom otherwise it wouldnt be occupied as we couldnt furnish it this Winter an was. That would make us three sleeping rooms in all. I shall try some of those pickles. Yours were the nicest I ever tasted. You know Dingman's folks dont you - she is Sister to Hattie Burch. They live here.

I met him yesterday: I believe they call him Gideon. He wanted to know when you was coming. He said he used to know you. Do you remember him? Yes! I will let the farm to the same man. I guess it will be the better way. I might write to this other party and find out what he would be willing to pay then I would know better whether this other man is giving what it is worth. They talk of having a Kindergarten connected with the school in this ward: if they do. I shall let Alice go the fall term. She is perfectly bewitched to go to school. She has never been a day in her life. The Sons of Veterans have a picnic tomorrow. I am

invited to go but will not as they cross the River in boats: and thats something I wouldnt do. I suppose they will have a good time. They can for all of me. They dont think Josh Randall can live going with consumption. Nell died two years ago. Silas is a Dr. and so is Net? Did Grade send you her childrens pictures. They are very nice looking but her boy. 6 mo. younger than Alice is a terror. But he is a handsome child. You have heard of Lo Hagen - he is dead he is Hod's? Father. My shed is getting full - It is 10 minutes of 11 - must stop & get dinner. I guess I will drop a line to that other party that wrote about the place. He is a lumber man at Albert unclear Good Bye Love & a kiss Your Mary Write as soon as you get this. Good Bye

Stevens Point. Aug 14. "96. Dear Mother. The camp meeting is just out and the last dog hung. Well:  I had a stand and cleared $7.00 Dont you think that better than nothing. I had to pay $3.00 for the ground: and $3.50 for a girl to help me and had first $7.00 for my self. I am tired as a dog and the house is a fright. It will take me a week to get straightened around again I made at the rate of 50 cts. a day. I want to go blackberrying this next week. They are very plenty around here they say.

As i have got my hand in at running a standI intend to have one when Buffalo Bill has his show here the 4th of Sept. that will not be as tiresome as it lasts only one day. The first time I go to town will see where I can get the ground for to puttee tendon. I think I have done pretty well:  I have $20.00 now of my own, including the $2.00 you sent me. I am writing this out doors it is so hot in the house. Havent we had terrible hot weather this last week or so. I have worried about you for fear you would be overcome by the heat. I hope you didnt go out these awful hot days

Dan had to stop work one day and go to bed before he come home. I kept in the shade as much as possible. They claim this is going to be a terrible hard Winter I have $20.00 and intend to hang on to it. We was just getting a little money ahead when Dan made up his mind he would have a wheel? so our Summer earnings so far went for that. He acted just posessed: and declared he wouldnt do anothertop? of work until he got a wheel and didnt. I must get Supper. Wish I had something awful good. Dan has came so must get at something to eat. Dont know

what it will be. I feel so flagged out how I wish I could go to a resturant just once how good it would seem. I get so tired of my own cooking. Good bye Ma.From your Mary Love & a kiss Good bye Write Soon

Sunday Stevens Point Sept 19 '96. Dear Mother. - I first sent a letter to you last night but will write you again today. I've been thinking if we had that money of Kelley we might build a house to rent and Dan could work on it this Winter: if he could get the cellar & foundation in this fall. I should want to get a lot near the  Normal & High School: for that is considered a fine residence place. Lots over there sold a year ago for $500.00 but as times are hard: can be bought now for less. I should build a cottage house as they are the most desirable to rent: Dan has

built a number of them & they rent for $12.00 per month. Supposing we had to run a little debt it wouldnt be long before it would be all paid for & bringing in a good income $144.00 per year. All these houses rent to R.R. people & they can afford to pay high rent as they get big pay themselves. Let me know in regard to it by return mail. It would be a good investment. He could get it all ready to plaster the first thing in the Spring & have it ready to rent by the first of June. How did you make out with that estate. Has it been settled yet. When do you expect to start for home. It is almost impossibl for men to get work

here. Dan is lucky just now but he only gets $1.75 per day. Dan & Alice are over in the woods after sweet acorns. The plaster is drying very nicely A lovely time of year to put it on. He puts the last coat on one week from tomorrow. I wish I could have the house painted on the outside this fall. When it is all finished &painted it will be a beauty. Just the right distance from town to suit me if I have a horse. And so much travel on the main road that goes to the paper mill. What do you care if you are thin just have one taken for me if you don't want any more. Get it taken & send me one next time you write. I shall expect it - dont disappoint me.

Dan & Alice are coming with their basket full of acorns. It is her delight to go in the woods. She grows like a weed. how I wish you could see her. She talks so much about her Grandma. I must close & write to the man that has the place in Minn. I have rented it to him for another year. He pays $100.00& taxes & builds a fence around it we furnish the wire. I think that is pretty good for these times. Dont you? Good bye Ma From Your Mary Love & a kiss Good bye Good night

Eldorado. Oct.19 96 Dear Mother. - I will drop you a line I am down to Uncle Johns I am going home Saturday so when you write direct to Stevens Point. Why havent you written before. I hope you are not sick. Write as soon as you are not sick. Write as soon as you get this. The folks that live in the Grand St. house in Oshkosh are going to move out. Have got a chance to rent it again but the folks have children. i will go there and see to it. If I can get a family in that havent any children I would like it.

Write as soon as you get this I got the interest from Mr. Kelley. The plastering is all done at home. Potatoes only 10 cts. per bu. Onions 25 cts per lb. Butter 18 cts per lb. Love & a kiss. From Your Mary Good bye I cant write with this pen.
Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Binghamton. New York.
STEVENS POINT, JUL 14 3:30 PM Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Binghamton. New York.
Postmark unclear Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Binghamton. New York.
STEVENS POINT SEP2 930 PM 96 Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Binghamton. New York.
ELDORADO 1896 WIS. Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Binghamton. New York.

"Happy New Year" Sunday Evening Stevens Point Jan. 3 "97 Dear Mother, Your letter rec'd containing Money Order and Five Dollars. I have written to Oshkosh to see how much the taxes are:  expect an answer soon. Will pay them as soon as I get word. I am real well now feeling better then I have all Summer. I was never so glad to hear from you as I was this letter. I was lonesome & your letter done one so much good. Alice is writing & Dan is reading. how did you spend Christmas & New Years.

We are having very queer Winter weather. It has rained off & on for the past week today it has rained hard almost all day. It seems just like Spring the ground is bare. I suppose the roads are almost impassable. Dan made Alice a cupboard for Christmas& got her some dishes. She thinks they are awful nice. I shall be so glad when you come. Dan going to the paper mill Tomorrow to see if he can get some work if not I dont know how we will get through the Winter. He had to borrow $6.25 to pay his Insurance. For my part I wish it was Spring. I'm much obliged for that

knit shirt & veil. I never see as nice a vest as that of that kind. I got a letter from Uncle John the other day he says the baby weighs 16 1/2 lbs. Old Mrs. Watson is dead also Mr. Skinner. Uncle Johns Brother is living with them. If I go down there again I shall not go near Amelia's she treated me like a dog. she thinks she is so smart. I will show her something some day. Time will tell. I will send you Alice's pictures in a day or so. I must not write any more. Good night. Love & a kiss From your Mary. Good bye

box contains every thing nice. I can hardly wait until it comes I'm as bad as Alice. I must not write any more but get supper. When are you going to start for home. Love & a kiss From your Mary Good bye write write Stevens Point. Jan. 22. "97. Dear Mother. - Your letter recd today. I was glad to hear from you & know you are well: I was so disappointed last Saturday night. I got it into my head you was coming that night and had supper all ready: and things all prepared for you. I thought sure you would come with this Pension. I find I have to wait. I wonder if the time will ever come when I will see you again. If you dont come before long I will take Alice and see you there. This is a terrible disagreeable

day. The wind blows & the air is full of snow that cuts first like sand. We have had a lovely Winter so far the coldest it has been is 10 degrees below zero the only draw back the lack of snow enough for sleighing. I got the Pension Draft. I'm a thousand times obliged for it: I will use a couple dollars of it to get some cotton cloth & the rest will have to go for Insurance & taxes. The taxes here were $11.50 The places in Oshkosh are insured for three years so is this. When you sent the other money. I sent the Insurance Agt. in Oshkosh $10.00 & will have to send him $8.00 out of this. Before you get this the taxes will all be paid & I will be glad. We can have a

little breathing spell until another year. I'm going to sell my land in Dakota this Spring if I can get this off my hands if I can sell: will put up a house to rent. I shall be so glad when it comes Spring. If I have enough money left: I'm going to get about 50 lbs. pork & the same of beef. and I am going to have a quart of oysters for my self. Won't I have a feast. I wrote to Mr. Lamb some time ago in regard to money but did not hear a word from him I have written today about butter if I can get any thing from them even $1.00 worth it will keep the Note good.The young folks down to Mr. Lambs put in a good deal of style. Lizzie & Willie & Myria

have bought a piano it cost $400.00 I heard. It is lovely. Of course Lambs folks dont have anything to do with it. they got a new buggy last Summer & new sewing machine. I should think it would look better to put the worth of that piano toward out debt. What do you suppose the young folks care. Mrs. lamb seemed ashamed of the piano. I wrote those folks in the Stoff place. that if they didnt pay their rent they could vacate & he wrote back & said it was impossible to pay anything now but would pay every dollar in the Spring. Shall Let them stay or make them get out.

Stevens Point. Jan 26 '97. Dear Mother. I am going down town, so will drop you a few lines. We have had a terrible cold spell. - Mercury 26 degrees below zero. - with a high wind. - it has lasted for 15 days now. Today is it a little warmer. - only 14 degrees below. - I will go to town today & perhaps it will moderate by tomorrow so I can wash. I dread the washing in cold weather. This is our first real cold snap we have had. Alice has been to the Kindergarten every day. - she would cry her eyes out if she couldnt.

The taxes are all paid in Oshkosh. - That is on yours. - but we cant pay our until Dan gets something to do. The taxes are very high. - they were $17.10 unclear on the Stobb place. - $4.28 on the vacant lot across the street & $11.40 on the Grant St. place. The tax on this place here was $11.50 They are all paid now. I got $5.00 worth of groceries with your money but will put it back as soon as we can. I will keep track of all we use & make it right in the Spring when he gets to work. I dont propose you will keep us. That is his place to do. I first got a letter from Grace - she said Mrs. Ash was dead & that place goes to Mrs.

Lamb but out of it they have go to pay Mr. Lang $2000. They are some ahead as the place is worth about $5000 dollars. Then they can have everything they raise on it before half went to Ash. We stand more of a chance to get our pay now than we have for years. I havent heard a word from them since I wrote in regard to butter. They out to be keep us in Butter the year around. If I can, I'm going to to get a cow of them in the Spring. Perhaps they will all put on style now but I guess not. It is 11 o'clock, I must get dinner so as to have it all ready when Alice comes home. Good bye. Love & a kiss From your Mary. Write soon
Alice talks more about that book you are going to send her. She is all books any way. Good bye. I cant hardly wait myself.

Stevens Point. Mar. 8 "97. Dear Mother. - Your letter just rec'd. - will answer it right away. I am so glad you are coming. Did you go to Washington to the anauguration- I see they had a big time.- I wish I had half the money that was spent - I would be satisfied. I suppose times will brighten up right away I see a tarriff is going to be put on Things right away. How i wish we could get some sugar.- but we cant as we havnt the money.

to, we havent paid for the lots yet and cant pay the interest until Dan gets to work. It was due last month but cant pay it. I think a carpenter has the poorest trade thare is for he has work such a short time, and the rest of the year lays around & eats it up. I'm just about tired of it myself. Dan cant earn enough to support us through the Winter without running in debt: so when he gets work, I tell him it takes half of the Summers wages to straighten up

with: so it leaves very little for clothes and things that are necessary my a familly. Speaking about clothes I dont have any only what you send. I am waering the shawl you got for me before you went away so you can judge as to my dress. I havnt had a hat this Winter wore an old fur cap I got four years ago.- I cant go to Church or any whare else. for the want of clothes. All I have had to wear on my feet this Winter are low shoes or slippers with rubbers. So do you wonder at my rejoicing to see Spring. Dan is sick, and has been for a week so he doesnt go out door.- I have all the out door chores to do. Well: I for one will be glad when it is Spring. I sometimes get so discouraged I dont know what to do. Winter soon Good bye - Your Mary. Love & a kiss - Good bye.-

The things in that box were admired by all who see them. Also the valentines I was the only in the neighborhood that got a valentine. Alice was wild over hers. She thinks more of that box of perfumery you sent. It was just what she wanted. She is growing so fast. She can hardly wait until you come. What time do you think you will be here. Let me know, so I can meet you at the depot. It will be the happiest moment of my life. when I see you. I lay awake nights + think of you,- and wonder if you would know me, if we should meet some where else. I dont believe you would. I dont look one bit as I used to. I am so fleshy. I weigh 156 lbs. Helen looks the same as every, only a little older. She is awful poor, I dont think we could do anything at the bakery business here.- there are so many of them: Send me your picture when you write also a lock of hair. By the way my hair is coming all out.- Ive lost half of it this Winter.

Stevens Point.- March 21" 97. Dear Mother.- I looked for a letter from you all last week: and as I didnt hear from you, will write. What kind of weather are you having there.- we have had terrible cold weather for March- a number of mornings it was 13 degrees below zero. Dan has been sick for the last two weeks, but is so he is out now My! I hope he will get work right away as we need the money so bad. It has has rained a good deal for the last week. It is snowing this afternoon. I shall be glad when the Spring comes. Tomorrow is my birthday. I am 35 years old. It doesnt seem as if I was that old but I guess I look it: It seems as if I had grown awful old this Winter.

When do you think of starting. I hope before long. The things you sent have been admired & admired by all who see them & they wondered how you could pack so much in the box. I had a letter from Uncle John.- Their baby has awful breakings out on its face. I havnt heard a word from Lambs folks yet.- dont you think it strange they dont write about the butter.- Not a word do I hear. If you only had money to buy up a car load of sugar: if you can get it for 2 1/2 cts per pound. my - you could make a big pile of money. it is 5 cts. here. Grace expects to be sick every day.- she will have three then:- if it lives. Grace has nine children.- one is enough for me. Alice is well & fat as a pig. Write as soon as you get this. I hope you are not sick from your Mary. Love & a kiss.

Wednesday.- I did not get this mailed until now.- so will write a few lines more. Had a letter from Hoddie saying they had another little girl down stairs - she weighed 8 1/2 lbs. So Grace has one boy & two girls now. I hope she will get along all right. I guess I have had a dozen chance to sell the Minn. place this Spring.- you don't want to ever sell do you. I had a letter from a man last night that wanted to buy it. I got a letter from Geo. Hurd in the morning, saying he thought as man would write once, as he had given him my address. Geo. said land was worth from 40 to 45 dollars per acre which ours is. I thought it good of Geo. to inform me: as I had no idea what land was bringing. The man said he would give $25 per acre. Wasnt

he going to make quite a speck - almost double his money.- I wish we could go thare to-live. Don't you think you would like it- thare. If you wouldnt I shouldnt think of going, as I will once be separated from you again. Don't you think of starting for home until the ground is settled. They are having terrible washouts all over. I would be afraid to go from here to Oshkosh now. Start as soon as the ground is settled. Let me know when you are coming & I will meet you at the depot.- I'm going to see the Dakota place if I can & put up two houses to rent near the Normal. A house that will rent for $12.00 the year around, will cost $600.00 and the lot $400.- making $1000.00 I'm in hopes to get $2000. for the Dakota place. Farming land will come right up now that a tarriff is put put on things. Good bye. From your Mary.

Stevens Point. April. 21" 97. Dear Mother,- I just rec'd your letter today, was glad to hear from you.- I wrote the other day, in regard to the watch.- and hope you have got it by this time.- I would hate to part with my wach as it is a splendid time keeper. Just the same make as my old one.- I think the chain a beauty. I guess you will write when you learn how stupid we were in regard to the watch.- I never see one like that before.- my old one had a little slide I had to pull out of the side.- then set it with the stem.- The watch is all right.- I am very much pleased with it. The reason I inquired about it so closely. - I thought it was broken and someone had cheated you.- Take it all back- I was to blame: not anyone else. The watch is all right.- & just what I wanted.- but never dreamed of having one again. I shan't tell anyone it was a second hand watch.- I told Cook's folks you had carried it about three months.- intending to bring it to me: but made up your mind you would send it for my birth day. Anyone to examine it would know it wasnt just new.- but how new it is,- they never will knew by my telling them. Write us soon as you get this. From your Mary- Love & a kiss. Good bye- write

I am going to take it to a jewelers + have it cleaned sometime.- it will look a good deal nicer. What did you have to pay for the watch chain.- Dan paid $22.00 for my old one.- $12.75 for the chain. I presume you got this at a bargain. I wish you wouldnt wait a month before you come.
Can't you set some date.- so I will know exactly. Work is very dull here at present. Dan thinks of going down to Branden to see what he can do there:- they are going to build a new school house.- to cost ($10,000) Ten thousand dollars.- we just got a letter from Grace + she says they have started two houses there + going to build up Weinstocks store than burnt last Winter.-
If Dan goes he will go with his wheel + I will drive down for a visit: but shan't be gone long as I don't want to leave the house alone. I shall make garden first. I wish we could sell this for a good price, + go down that way + get about 20 acres near Brandon or in that vacinity.- so we could keep a horse, cow + chickens.- and at the same time it would be near enough for Dan to work, as he can go like the wind on his wheel. I could sell the house _ one lot for $1400 fourteen hundred dollars + I will put a tag in the house "For Sale."
I like it here as far as location is concerned; but think it would be so pleasant to live down that way where we are acquainted with every one. It seems like home to me. Doesnt it to you
No matter where you want to live I would be contented if I was only with you whether in Wis. or New York. If you like it better there we will go there. I hear Binghamton is a beautiful city.

Stevens Point May 7th 97
Dear Mother,
Your second letter recd. today should have written before but Alice has had the chicken pox and it kept me busy. She is out now getting along nicely. I'm glad she has had it now it is over with. Thank you a thousand times for the money in both letters. I had the Dr. once for Alice & that took $1.00 of it. With the rest I am giving to get her a hat & shoes. I guess Alice & I would fared pretty slim this Winter if it hadn't been for you. I havent had a cent of money only what you have sent me and you bet I keep it myself. Dan doesnt know I have any money half the time. He is working for Edwards now just commenced Monday he has about 4 weeks work there will get cash every Sat night but that is all the good it will do me

as it has got to go for debts There isnt any use talking he has got to get into something so he can earn money Winter's as well as in the Summer. Every Spring we come out in debt & it takes half the Summer to get caught up again we just begin to get a little ahead: when it comes cold weather, and his work stops then? sits down & eats it up & more to: I dont know what a person would go into these times to make anything. I think the carpenters trade the poorest trade in the world with out something to go with it. I wish I could make $1.00 a day or even 50 cts a day. I have  my hands full at present making garden cleaning house and trying to sew. I going to work in the garden all day tomorrow perhaps I can get it done. I like to have a garden of my own. I dont like stuff that lays around the stores.

Dont you remember you sent me some "Graino" last Winter. I thought it was splendid. I don't like coffee since we use Posturn? Cereal it is almost the same as Graino. Do you use this Graino. Dont you like it awful well. I ought to go to town tomorrow. Will you surely  be here the 4th of July. I shall expect you then: You said you had a couple waists & skirts for me. I wish I had them new it would save me buying couldn't you send them: it wouldn't cost more than 25 cts Why dont you send your picture. Send it the next time you write. Dan may go down to Brandon to work they are going to build a school house to cost $10,000 wont it make them squirm? to pay taxes.
Cant you come before the 4th I cant hardly wait. I must close for this time. Write as soon as you can Good bye. Yours with Love From your Mary Love & a kiss Good bye Ma. Write.

Stevens Point. May 24" 97.
"Sunday"
Dear Mother.-
Your letter seed? yesterday.- was glad to hear from you and to know you are well. I am real well at present. Much obliged for the money you sent. I'm afraid you robbed? your self.- didn't you! Dan has got done work out to Edwards.- and has gone down to Almond: to see about work.
He started last Thursday afternoon and I expected him home Friday: but didnt come.- he has either gone to work or count get work.- and gone on to Oshosh. I expect to hear from him in the morning.- There is quite a little building going on here: but it is mostly brick or stone.- so share? is very little carpenter work. If our house wasnt rented for a year.- I should move back again this Summer: as it is, I can't go until Spring. We have a very pleasant place here; but I am so

tired of the sand.- We have had the worst sand storms this Spring. we even had just get there house cleaned: and after one of those storms.- you would never surmise it had ever been cleaned.- I think it is hurting my eyes- they ache all the time: + I know its from the sand. Its impossible to be out in one of these storms.- it is just blinding.- I would like to sell this place: for it wouldnt pay to bother renting it: as long as we didnt live here. Can I put a sign up "For Sale"- I think I could get $1400 for it.- if so.- that would be making well.- I should miss the soft water and the lovely shade.- but there are trees down that way.- and as for schools.- they are just as good in Oshkosh as here. 
I wouldnt be hired to live here another Summer: for the sand is so terrible.
My eyes feel as if they were full of sand all the time: and I suppose they are. If Dan goes to Oshkosh I will drive down the last of next week.- I cant go now as this is my sick week, and another thing, I wouldnt go

until I get that Express Package. I am so anxious to get it. I don't know what to do. I shall figure on your being here the- 4th.- Be sure and come.
I ought to go out to Minn. This Summer. + see if I couldnt make some arrangements about getting some of the land broke: but cant.- with out I could drive those.- for I havent any money.
I am so pleased with my watch: I wear it almost all the time. I should feel lost with out it. How much did you have to pay for it.- I guess as far as wear it is almost a good as new.
Get your picture takin and send me one.- send me one when you write again. Did I send you my shirt measure.- my shirt measure is 41 in.- Bust 36 in.- Waist 30 in.
I weigh 136 lbs so you see I am awful large. I dont like to be so fat. but don't know how to prevent it. I presume I will get thin after awhile. You wouldnt know me. I'm so fleshy. 
The heat almost kills me. + I'm just

as sensative to the cold. Alice has just woke up, so I must get our supper.
Wish I had some thing good: but havent.- Write as soon as you get this. With Love + a kiss I will say good bye-
Yours with Love.
From your Mary.
Write Soon-
Good bye.

Alice does her own composing.
Stevens Point. June. 3rd "97.
Dear Mother,-
I do not owe you a letter.- but will write a few lines.
Dan has gone to Branden. went Wednesday I wrote to R. C. Kelly in regard to work: so it wasnt more than a week before he wrote for Dan to come at once. Dan is working with Kelly's Brother-in-law.- Ed. Meaghe's. perhaps you remember him.- I dont, but the name is familiar. I got a letter from Dan: he is working for John Fairbanks.- I remember him. dont you.- He used to work for Aunt Susan. Dan said he would have work down that way all Summer- My! isnt that good.- Of course it is late to commence but if he has work until cold weather: it will help us out all right. I am going to drive down this week.- or after I get that package from you.- I will be gone about two weeks.

I cant be gone long at a time.- on account of my garden.- also the insurance.
Dan said John lives four miles East of Branden. He live near the Caplain Plocker place: only a little ways from Fairwater. Dan gets $1.73- per day + board. Perhaps he will get $2.00 on the next job. I hope so at least. I know if we lived down that way. he would have all the work he could do.- for he is a first-class workman. I wish we could sell this for a good sum + go down that way. I have the tooth ache today.- for the first time.- I have never had a tooth pulled yet. I ought to have this filled: but hate to spare the money. I cant stand this long. Must have something done with it.
Alice wrote to you I see. I guess she frogot how to spell beauty.- I think she does first-rate.- dont you. Write as soon as you get this. I shan't go down below until I hear from you. Yours with Love
From Your Mary.
Good bye- Love + a kiss.

Brandon. July 12 "97.
Dear Mother.
I will write a few lines.- have just got the package- my: I think every thing very nice. I had it sent down to Fonddu Lac from the point.- and Grace and I drove out after it.
I think the skirts handsome. also the waists. The gloves are to small. I will send them back. as soon as I go to Town
Every one is stuck on my skirts. I am going to Oshkosh this week: but if you write direct to Brandon just the same. Dan gets $4.75 per day and board

It looks now as if it would last until it freezes up. I hope so it at least.
How I wish we could get a small farm. one of about 40 acres- so I could keep a few cows + hens + bees. 
Dan could work at his trade a good deal. + we could raise were then we needed off of it. What do you say to selling the place in the Point + putting at unclear a small farm down this way.
We could do well.
We have had terrible hot weather for the past four weeks. but it is cooler now. This morning it is cold enough for a fire. I am holding the baby.- so my writing wont be very nice

I first heard Aunt and Uncle Heman were living together again. Mrs. Sexton is dead.
Uncle John Jaquins is dead. Had you heard of it.
Grace had a letter from one of his girls.
I havnt seen Aunt Frannie + Emily yet.- it has been so hot.- I havnt been any where. I hope you are well. I wrote you a postal + thought I would get a letter from you Sat. perhaps I will get one today. It is gluest?- 
unclear time so I will close- I hope I will hear from you soon.
Yours with Love-
From your Mary.
Love + a kiss.
Write soon.

Brandon. July 26 "97.
Dear Mother- 
I just got your letter: and will ans. it right away.- Dan is working in Brandon this week and boarding to. Aunt Frannie's and I came over Saturday night. and we all visited at Emily's yesterday. Had a very nice time. Aunt Frannie was 75 yrs. old Friday.- + smart as a cricket.
I got the Pension Draft and the bill you sent.- also the stamps.- Many thanks for the money _ stamps, I won't cash the Draft until you come. Tell me when you

will come.- so I will be in Steven's Point.- Dan will have work here until it freezes up.- I think.- I can hardly wait until you come.
Write + let me know first- when you will be in the Point.- so I can get home.
Do you know what I would do if I was a man.- + could get $1000 I would go to the gold mines in Alaska
Of course it is a terrible undertaking but I would do it.- men have gone in those poor as poverty.- and came out millionairs.- Some go in without anything to tide them over with.- of course such slaive to death. I wish Dan was strong as he used to be.-

They are putting up a splendid school house here in B- and tearing down the old one. Dan is working on Mrs. Shorts building.- She has put up a monstrous building.- and they say mortgages everything she had. 
Short died long ago, I see in the paper that Mc. Miller of Oshkosh is dead.
ALice is asleep,- She + Emilys girls had a nice time together. Aunt Frannie didnt have any ink. so I have to write with a pen.
I had a chance to get cherries cheap, so I put up 2 bu.- I had 40 qts.- 
I paid $1.00 a bu. Black raspberries are only $1,00 a bu. I wish I could get

same.- I could get them all right: but the trouble is to get them home,
I am going to Oshkosh this week,- Direct your letters to Brandon.
Write as soon as you get this.- From your Mary. 
Love + a kiss.
Good bye-,
I am almost sorry we sold the place here in Brandon.- it is such a beautiful place.
Good bye
Write Soon.

Jan. 23rd, 1891,
Dear Friend Mrs Hurd
I Presume you will be somewhat surprised to receive a letter from me but it just come to my mind that I would drop you a line my family are in usual health excepting myself I have a very hard cold. If you will sell your place at Brandon, I would to have you write to me and tell me your price, and oblige me.
Yours sincerly
Mrs Sarah Acker.

Holdingford. Minn.
Jan. 5" 1921.
Just a line this morning: ("before the train comes") to let you know I seed your letter: also the notice of that mole? becoming due. You will have to pay the interest and have the work extended for 6 mo. as I can't pay it now.
Nice weather here.- just as good wheeling as sleighing.- if not better.
Auto's go all the time: the same as Summer. I have the worst cold I ever had.- but Ma is real well. Sleeps like a pig. I got Raymond some shoes for Christmas,

and they are to small. Got them at St. Cloud- John is going to change them Sat. afternoon; when Raymond can go along.
My head and neck and shoulders feel so bad all the time; its a task to write.- must write to Mr. Summers folks.- also Mrs. Cesebro- Havnt written but three letters since I have been here.- one to Mrs. Cook + two to Grace: besides yours. I think each day I will write letters all day: but when the time comes: I cant do it, I go to bed instead.
Good bye
Mary.

Scranton Oct 21
[1891]
Dear Mrs Hurd

Thanks for your kind letter which Mrs Reese brought me monday + spent the day with us. expecting me to go home with her, but I could not very well as Melvin is going to New York for a few days, + I want to stay with his wife until his return, and will probably not get to Mrs Reeses until Saturday. and of course must stay a few days there try and not get too lonesome, but you can get along so nicely with everything there that I dont have anything to do but enjoy myself try to do the same. am glad every thing is getting along so nicely

poor cat she is determined to dine on the little Birds. give love to Will + father, and they I suppose are having a nice quiet time with no one to plague them, if you should want me sooner drop a postal to Mrs Reese, with love 
Mrs Juliet E Corbett

Binghamton N. Y.
Mch. 3rd, 1898
My dear friend,
I thought I would answer your ever welcome letter which I received a long while ago but I have not had time to answer before as I have been so busy. We are all well and hope this letter will find you the same.
Gertie and family

are all well and Edna May walks all alone. Edna May was very much pleased with her valentine and snow-flake and well send a letter to your granddaughter before long. Gertie will write to you also,
Charlie and family are all well and send their love to you: Bessie is having a few holidays and is is spending them with me.
We are going to move on Walter Fling's farm this month.

I am glad you had lunch enough to last you through your journey.
Spring is peeping out now and then and I guess it will soon be here. I send my love to your daughter and family and my love and a kiss to you. I will close now remaining as every your loving friend,
Clara Jewell
P. S. Please answer soon don't wait as long as I did. good bye.

From Clara Jewell,

to Mrs. Ann A. Herd.

My dear friend
I was much surprised though happy in receiving a card from you the other day From the address I couldn't think for a moment who it was from then your address was not on full? so I was in doubt where to write you did not put on any state and the post mark was so dim could only make out an N but putting all together included you must have gone to your early home in unclear You letter was dated in Feby.? but as it was misdirected to Sioux City did not reach me till this

last week so unclear hasten to reply that I may hear from you again with full particulars of our friends you tell me of Aunt Susan's death had not heard of it before although I was thinking of her about the time I read your card. When did she die how, and was she sick long what disposition di she make of her property does Amelia still live on the farm and how many children has she
Where is your daughter Mary is she married or is she with you. I was in Redfield? several years ago and inquired after her and her cousin they told me they were neither of them there And is your sister Mary still living is she well What can you tell me of Uncle Herman's family I unclear one or two letters from uncle Herman

also from Helen after Aunt Jane died since then have heard nothing do not know where any of them are have often wished I did and would write to them I am so glad to have heard from you as I hate to give up the associations of old friends and I look back with pleasure of the many good visits I have had at your home more especially of the last one in Oshkosh and out trip together to Rush Lake My friend whom I went to visit at that time is living in Beloit Wis. have not seen her since that time Where is the old gentleman the was at your house when I was there have forgotten his name You tell me you have been there three years that your Father is still

living and very aged. Is he a great care and helpless will you that your permanent home - How is your health hope you are stronger than you used to be. Well now a word about myself I am just the same as I used to be just as holy 9don't improve with age) just as ugly have a pleasant home have Father & Mother with me They are both getting aged though quite well. Father is just 82 last Friday Mother is nearly 81. she is very feeble tho not sick I have a large house and keep boarders have from twelve to sixteen keep two girls so that I get along very easy I have two excellent girls so that I don't have to do any cooking that you know is the main thin in keeping boarders. My sister Mrs. Randall and her daughter live in Minnneapolis Sister Mary in Seattle Wash. now Augusta I hope you will write me very soon as I am anxious to know more about you. With much love Ever your Lizzie Peebles

Dear Augusta;

Y. and from there here to stay for two weeks. Ethel is a nice smart girl and

is her parent's idol.
Yesterday Kate + their Ethel Will, Edith + I celebrated at the soldier's Name went early in the morning + came home at 11 o'clock in the evening passed a very pleasant day - Edith can run all over a 40 acre lot if find? lithes?, she has cut three double teeth since you were here and has another nearly through.
she is real worrisome today but oh, it is so hot we have had four old scorching days.
Mrs. Grossman was over and we were over there also this baby does not attempt walking

yet.
I had a letter from Agnes Wood to day they seem anxious for me it came up there but it is a terrible struggle in my mind to resolve to go but expect I'll have to.
Will is working at $2.00 a day till the factory.
opens shingling houses.

Jool + Nellie went to Dakota last Wednesday suppose they spent their fourth then.

is surely worth 4 c a yd- Oscar Stockmeyer is there visiting will stay all the week at least.

Will + Helen.-

Sept 9th 1863
Dear Father
After so long a silence I will try + break the spell I intended to write before but have been unable to do so since we seed your last, for about 3 weeks I have been sorely afflicted with biles, one on my right arm caused me a great deal of pain I took cold in it my arm swelled full I think it will soon be well since it is opened Augusta's health is good she expects Ana will be here in a few days + Olive runs alone she is very fleshy she is the greatest mimic I ever saw we cannot do anything but that she will try to imitate. John has gone to one of our neighbors to help him thrash wheat turns out much better than expected, and sells at 18D 80cts, per buschel I suppose Heman wrote you about the land he paid us $100 each I enclose a certificate of the balance as it sight that we should take it, surely we stood in great need + it will do us a great deal of good but that does not answer my question. Perhaps you would like to know how we disposed of our portion

mine was paid toward our farm + Augusta sented hers I was glad to get it I never have helped John along + he works so hard 
The draft does not take place yet some say it does not in this county Mary P. Slockue has been up on a visit she is slowly fading? away. I do not think she will live a year A week ago sunday I went up to the burying ground George has a beautiful resting place, when he was buried, there was but one grave, now I should think there were fifty, Tis about 16 + sods from our house but not in sight, The yard is laid out in lots and sold a very nice fence has been built around it + last spring The association set out evergreens around it and expended much time + money I hear from Charles quite often soon he will be with you again perfectly cured. I think of the idea of never becoming a soldier Give my love to Grandpa O how I wish I could come + see you all we cannot afford it this fall I have written this very badly I write on a paper in my lap so you must excuse all mistakes write as soon as you get so we may know that the certificate is safe  
Mary P. Stocklers

Friend Augusta
My Sister Matilda wished me to write to you for her, and see if you would come and stay with her as you did unclear Warrens. Matilda has been sick with the unclear she is around the house and wails unclear but that is all she is able to do. I don't think she will be able to do her work alone in a long time if ever. They live in Afton village and all there is of them is her and her husband so you see the work won't be light she has a young girl at work for her now and can keep her but she does not know how to cook good

and she said she knew you could and then you and she had been acquainted so long it would seem a little different. Now Augusta will you please answer this as soon as you receive it and let me know if you will come and when and whether you will come to Bainbridge first or whether you will stop to Afton She would be glad to have you come immediately. but please write whether you can come or not for there is another woman I think perhaps we can get if you cannot Please direct your letter to me and I will let her know all about it. If you stop off at Afton write the day and the train you will be on and they will meet you to the train. Mrs. Melvin A. Yale
Bainbridge, N.Y.
